Sam Stebbins

April 25th, 2025 ( 24/7 Wall St. - Delivered by Newstex )

For much of the last half decade, wage gains made by the typical American worker have been wiped out by historic inflation. The consumer price index hit a multi-decade high in mid-2022, and partially as a result, real, inflation-adjusted incomes fell by nearly 9% over the two years begining in the second quarter of 2020. During that period, the imbalance between wages and the cost of living gave way to reduced purchasing power and lower living standards for millions of American households.

24/7 Wall St. Key Points:

In the last year of available data, wages for the typical American worker went up by about 3%, more than enough to offset the effects of inflation.

Still, many of the economic forces benefitting the labor force as a whole are fueling meaningful pay cuts in dozens of occupations, and millions of American workers are being impacted.

Also: Discover the next Nvidia

Even though real, inflation-adjusted incomes have yet to return to their all-time high, reported in 2020, wage growth has generally outpaced inflation in the last few years. As of May 2024, the typical American worker earned $49,500, a year-over-year increase of about 3%. Accounting for inflation, real wages climbed about 1% over roughly the same period.

Still, these broad economic trends do not tell the whole story, as millions of Americans are currently employed in occupations that are reporting meaningful wage declines. And these pay cuts are only exacerbated by inflation rates that remain above the Federal Reserve's 2% target.

Using data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 24/7 Wall St. identified the jobs where wages are falling the fastest. We reviewed median annual wage data for hundreds of detail-level occupations for both May 2023 and May 2024, and identified those that reported the largest decreases over that period. All supplemental data is also from the BLS.

Among the more than 800 occupations with available data, 46 reported wage declines of at least 2% in the last year. In a handful of these jobs, wages have gone down by over 10%. Depending on the occupation, these pay cuts have resulted in a nominal loss of anywhere from about $1,200 to $37,600 per year for the typical worker. Notably, however, the vast majority of occupations on this list still pay more than most jobs in the U.S. labor market. (Here is a look at the remote jobs that pay more than office jobs.)

The occupations on this list employ some 3.4 million Americans and span a range of industries, including transportation, social sciences, and resource extraction. The largest share of occupations on this list are in education or arts, entertainment, and media.

Despite falling wages, most jobs on this list are reporting rapid employment growth. Over the last year, total employment grew by more than 2% in 27 of the occupations on this list. For context, overall employment across all occupations increased by 1.5% over the same period. Meanwhile, only 14 of these jobs employ fewer workers now than they did a year ago. (Here is a look at t he American presidents who oversaw the best job markets in U.S. history.)

These are the jobs where pay is falling the fastest.

Why It Matters

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, wage gains were wiped out by historic levels of inflation. More recently, however, most workers have seen increased buying power and an improved standard of living, as inflation has cooled and incomes have continued to rise. Still, there are dozens of occupations in which median wages have fallen in the last year - and millions of Americans have been impacted.

urn:contentItem:6DYD-FJC3-RS14-F2CX-00000-00Growing Concerns About Wildfires in Carolina Thanks to Kindling Left by Helene2025-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisGrowing Concerns About Wildfires in Carolina Thanks to Kindling Left by HeleneWilliam Rabb

As southern California continues to suffer from wildfires, officials in another part of the country fear their area could be next - thanks to tons of dry wood left over from Hurricane Helene's wind and flooding.

"The number one fire threat in western North Carolina seems to be all the trees on the ground," said Joe Stewart, vice president of government affairs for the Independent Insurance Agents of North Carolina. "There's a lot of concern about it."

Four months after Helene crushed much of western North Carolina and east Tennessee with unprecedented flooding and left piles and piles of uprooted trees and brush, insurance interests and fire management officials are increasingly worried about wildfires that could rival those seen in California in recent weeks.

Helene knocked down or uprooted trees over an estimated 820,000 acres of forestland in Carolina when it slogged through in late September, the Raleigh News & Observer reported. In Nantahala and Pisgah National Forests, Helene caused moderate to catastrophic damage to some 187,000 acres, vastly increasing the threat of wildfire, the North Carolina Forest Service said in a bulletin.

To help people clear some of the debris left by the unusually destructive storm, the service in October waived the requirement for burn permits in 21 counties. But it warned residents to use caution when burning debris.

Adding to the potential fuel for fire are the hundreds of new homes and commercial buildings that have sprung up in the region in the last decade, especially around the popular city of Asheville. As of 2020, more than half of North Carolina residents lived in wildland-urban interface areas shown to be a threat for increased wildfires, the NC Forest Service said.

"The topography also makes it difficult to reach and repair some places," Stewart added.

Few homeowners in the region have considered the risk of fire and many may not be fully insured. "A lot of people don't see secondary perils," Stewart said.

And although November was slightly wetter than in 2023, December brought less precipitation than it did the year before, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Much of this year so far, especially last week, has been unusually dry in much of the state, raising the fire threat level, authorities said.

Experts are now so concerned that they have planned a meeting next week, Jan. 28, to discuss the risk and ways to reduce it. North Carolina State University's Institute for Climate Studies in Asheville is hosting the gathering.

Compounding the potential risk from fire is a continuing shortage of firefighters in parts of the state, according to news reports. North Carolina saw a decline of almost 5,000 volunteer firefighters, from 2020 to 2023. That's when the North Carolina Association of Fire Chiefs put out an urgent call for more volunteers to sign up. But the numbers have changed little since then, the N&O has noted.

Another issue: Some in the state have blamed the homebuilders' lobby for pushing through legislation last year that limits local governments' abilities to heighten fire prevention and other regulations beyond what state building codes already require, news sites have reported. Firefighter organizations raised red flags last fall after the governor's veto of the legislation was overridden.

Wildfires in parts of the state could exacerbate insurance costs for some property owners in the region, costs that have risen steadily for homes, businesses and mobile homes in recent years. In the most recent increase, North Carolina's insurance commissioner, Mike Causey, announced last week that he had negotiated a 15% average rate increase for homeowner insurance. That came after the North Carolina Rate Bureau, basing its recommendation on data from property insurers, had asked for a 42% average increase.

Counties that endured historic flooding from Helene will see smaller increases than other parts of the state.

urn:contentItem:6DCY-HJV1-JCMC-W0W9-00000-00New York parks employee dies fighting fires; air quality warnings issued in N.Y., New Jersey2024-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisUS NEWSNew York parks employee dies fighting fires; air quality warnings issued in N.Y., New Jersey

A firefighter is silhouetted against a forest fire on Wednesday in Evesham, N.J. New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection via AP

POMPTON LAKES, N.J. - A New York parks employee died battling one of a number of wildfires in New Jersey and New York amid dry conditions that have prompted air quality warnings in both states, authorities said Sunday.



The worker died when a tree fell on him Saturday afternoon as he battled a major brush fire along the New York-New Jersey border, according to reports from the Eastern Dutchess County Fire and Rescue and the New York state forestry services.

"Rip brother your shift is over job well done," the New York State forestry services post said.

New York State Police said they were investigating the death amid the fire in Sterling Forest located in Greenwood Lake and identified the victim as Dariel Vasquez, an 18-year-old state Parks and Recreation aide employed by the New York State Parks, Recreation, and Historic Preservation Department.

The fires in New York and New Jersey come as firefighters are also battling a wildfire in California.

The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection's Forest Fire Service reported the sprawling blaze had spread to 3.9 square miles near the border in Passaic County's West Milford and Orange County, New York. Officials said Sunday the blaze, dubbed the Jennings Creek wildfire, was now threatening 14 Greenwood Lake structures as well as two New Jersey homes and eight buildings in that state's Long Pond Ironworks Historic District.

Advertisement

Health advisories were issued for parts of New York, including New York City, and northeastern New Jersey due to unhealthy air quality due to smoke from the fires. People were urged to limit strenuous outdoor physical activity if possible; those especially sensitive included the very young and very old and people with ailments such as asthma and heart disease.

New Jersey officials, meanwhile, reported 75% containment of a 175-acre fire in the Pompton Lakes area of Passaic County that was threatening 55 homes, although no evacuations had been ordered.

Progress was also reported on fires in the Bethany Run area on the border of Burlington and Camden counties in Evesham and Voorhees townships; a blaze along the Palisades Interstate Parkway in Englewood Cliffs in Bergen County; and the Pheasant Run wildfire in the Glassboro wildlife protection area of Gloucester County.

Prosecutors in Ocean County on late Saturday afternoon announced arson and firearms charges in connection with a 350-acre Jackson Township fire that started Wednesday. They said it was sparked by magnesium shards from a shotgun round on the berm of a shooting range. Officials said firing that kind of "incendiary or tracer ammunition" was barred in the state. The majority of the blaze has been contained, officials reported Friday.

In Massachusetts, one wildfire among several fueled by powerful wind gusts and dry leaves burned more than 200 acres in the Lynn Woods Reservation, a municipal park that comprises about 3.4 square miles in the city 10 miles north of Boston.

"This is a dry spell we have not seen during this time of year in many years," the Lynn Fire Department said in a statement on social media as firefighters continued to battle the blaze, blaming its intensely on low humidity as well as winds and dry leaves on the ground.

Advertisement

It was one of many brush fires that cropped up across the region. In Foxborough, fire crews said that containing a wildfire at the F. Gilbert Hills State Forest would be a "a multi-day event."

Wind gusts topped 40 mph on Saturday, and less-powerful gusts continued Sunday.

Firefighters and forest agencies warned against outdoor burning.

The drier-than-normal weather is expected to continue, and virtually all of New England is categorized as being in drought or being abnormally dry. Most of the region was expected to see some light rain Sunday night, but there are no large rainfall events in the forecast, said National Weather Service meteorologist Jerry Combs.

Firefighters in California were also battling a scattering of blazes over the weekend, including one north of Los Angeles that had burned more than 100 structures.

Evacuation orders were downgraded to warnings for residents in several areas of Ventura County, where the Mountain Fire held at around 32 square miles and was 26% contained, authorities said.

urn:contentItem:6DMF-WB91-JBSP-143Y-00000-00Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia Researchers Detail Findings in Climate Change (Long-term climate change analysis in northeast and eastern India)2024-12-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEUniversiti Kebangsaan Malaysia Researchers Detail Findings in Climate Change (Long-term climate change analysis in northeast and eastern India)


2024 DEC 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in climate change. According to news originating from Selangor, Malaysia, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Global climate change and landform alteration are correlated with a high impact on rainfall, land surface temperature (LST), vegetation conditions, and soil moisture."


The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia: "This study examines rainfall, temperature, vegetation condition, moisture, and drought index to identify the decadal change from 2002 to 2021 using Landsat and global Standardized Precipitation Evapotranspiration Index-base (SPEIbase) data in Google Earth Engine (GEE). In between 20 years, 50.54 mm of mean rainfall decreased in the study area while 6.31 °C of LST increased in the entire region. The most affected states are Bihar, Jharkhand, and West Bengal. Similarly, in northeast India, Assam, Tripura, and Meghalaya have huge effects on temperature variation. The green space (0.158), and moisture (-0.082) fluctuated mainly in Mizoram, Arunachal Pradesh, Manipur, and Tripura states. The SPEI has increased (-0.232) in Bihar, Manipur, Tripura, Assam, and Meghalaya."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The analysis observed that decreased rainfall and high-temperature variation may impact crop production, moisture loss, cyclonic affected in West Bengal coastal areas, floods in the Brahmaputra River basin and Bihar, droughts, and urban heat island-related effects. Some policies like reduction of forest fire (northeast), flood (Assam), urban planning (West Bengal, Bihar, and Assam), industrial pollution, and jhum cultivation decrease can improve the climate change in those states, India."
For more information on this research see: Long-term climate change analysis in northeast and eastern India. Geomatics, Natural Hazards & Risk, 2024,15(1). (Geomatics, Natural Hazards & Risk - http://www.tandfonline.com/TGNH). The publisher for Geomatics, Natural Hazards & Risk is Taylor & Francis Group.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1080/19475705.2024.2409206.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Bijay Halder, Department of Earth Sciences and Environment, Faculty of Sciences and Technology, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia. Additional authors for this research include Zaher Mundher Yaseen.

urn:contentItem:6BTX-KVJ1-JBSP-122P-00000-00Beijing Forestry University Researcher Describes Research in Remote Sensing (A Forest Fire Prediction Method for Lightning Stroke Based on Remote Sensing Data)2024-04-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisREMOTE SENSINGBeijing Forestry University Researcher Describes Research in Remote Sensing (A Forest Fire Prediction Method for Lightning Stroke Based on Remote Sensing Data)


2024 APR 18 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in remote sensing. According to news reporting originating from Beijing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires ignited by lightning accounted for 68.28% of all forest fires in the Greater Khingan Mountains (GKM) region of northeast China."


Financial supporters for this research include National Key R&D Program of China; National Natural Science Foundation of China.
The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Beijing Forestry University: "Forecasting the incidence of lightning-triggered forest fires in the region is imperative for mitigating deforestation, preserving biodiversity, and safeguarding distinctive natural habitats and resources. Lightning monitoring data and vegetation moisture content have emerged as pivotal factors among the various influences on lightning-induced fires. This study employed innovative satellite remote sensing technology to swiftly acquire vegetation moisture content data across extensive forested regions. Firstly, the most suitable method to identify the lightning strikes that resulted in fires and two crucial lightning parameters correlated with fire occurrence are confirmed."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Secondly, a logistic regression method is proposed for predicting the likelihood of fires triggered by lightning strikes. Finally, the method underwent verification using five years of fire data from the GKM area, resulting in an AUC value of 0.849 and identifying the primary factors contributing to lightning-induced fires in the region."
For more information on this research see: A Forest Fire Prediction Method for Lightning Stroke Based on Remote Sensing Data. Forests, 2024,15(4). (Forests - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/forests/). The publisher for Forests is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/f15040647.

urn:contentItem:6DY6-RXM3-RY4C-2476-00000-00Did this military plane cause LA fires? No, it was dismantled in 2014 | Fact check2025-01-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisDid this military plane cause LA fires? No, it was dismantled in 2014 | Fact checkThe claim: Image shows laser-equipped plane that started LA wildfires

A Jan. 10 Facebook post (direct link, archive link) shows an airplane with a reflective device near the nose.

“Here’s your forest fire starter,” reads the caption on the post.

The post was shared more than 45,000 times in 10 days.

More from the Fact-Check Team:How we pick and research claims | Email newsletter | Facebook page

Our rating: False

The photo is from a 2007 announcement by the Air Force of developments with a prototype plane. The pictured aircraft was disassembled more than a decade ago.

Plane dismantled in 2014

The wildfires in and near Los Angeles that began Jan. 7 have claimed at least 27 lives as of Jan. 16. The ferocity of the blazes and the suddenness of their spread has fueled numerous baseless conspiracy theories about their causes, including that a laser or other directed energy weapon was used to start them.

The aircraft pictured in the post was equipped with a laser, but it had nothing to do with the fires. It was dismantled more than a decade ago, according to media reports and announcements from the military. The plane went through years of expensive tests that showed it wasn’t technically, financially or logistically viable as designed for its intended purpose of shooting down ballistic missiles.

The picture came from a June 28, 2007, announcement of the plane’s arrival at what was then Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland. The prototype airborne laser aircraft, later christened the YAL-1, featured the weapon in the nose of a Boeing 747. The laser was intended to shoot down missiles shortly after launch.

The program was costly to get off the ground and was already facing funding cuts by the time the YAL-1 made the flight to Andrews. It was inconsistent in testing, failing to knock down two of its first three targets. The aircraft also needed to be much closer than hoped to have a shot at successfully shooting down missiles.

After more than $5 billion was spent on the program, and knowing billions more would be needed to build and maintain each new plane, the program was shut down. The plane was shipped to a yard for retired aircraft in 2012 and by 2014 had been stripped for parts and scrapped, according to the Air Force.

Fact check: Clip shows plane crash in Chile in 2024, predating LA wildfires

Experts have pointed to a mix of high winds, low humidity and ongoing drought as key factors in the spread of the wildfires in southern California. The cause is under investigation. There is no evidence and no credible reports pointing to a blast from a directed energy weapon.

The false claim that lasers or other energy weapons are the actual cause of wildfires is not a new one. USA TODAY debunked claims that directed energy weapons were responsible for the 2023 Maui fires.

USA TODAY reached out to the social media user who shared the claim for comment but did not immediately receive a response.

urn:contentItem:6D2S-W601-DYG2-R3FC-00000-00Maine Agriculture Dept.: Maine State Forester Patty Cormier Elected President of the National Association of State Foresters2024-09-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisMaine Agriculture Dept.: Maine State Forester Patty Cormier Elected President of the National Association of State ForestersTargeted News ServiceAUGUSTA, Maine

The Maine Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry issued the following news:

The Maine Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry (DACF) proudly announces that Patty Cormier, Maine State Forester, has been elected President of the National Association of State Foresters (NASF). Cormier's election marks a significant milestone, as she becomes the first Maine State Forester to hold this prestigious position since Austin Wilkins 59 years ago. Cormier will serve a one-year term as NASF President, continuing her long-standing commitment to sustainable forestry and forest management.

"I am honored to step into this role and carry forward the legacy of Austin Wilkins, who was such a pivotal figure in Maine forestry," said Cormier. "This is a pivotal time for forest conservation, and I look forward to collaborating with state foresters from across the nation to elevate their voices and work with partners to find answers to challenges we all face."

"Patty's contributions to forestry in Maine and nationally make her very well qualified to lead NASF over the coming year," said DACF Commissioner Amanda Beal. "We are truly fortunate to have a State Forester who clearly has earned and enjoys the respect of her NASAF colleagues and those who have the privilege of working with her in Maine as well."

Cormier has served as Maine State Forester since 2019 and has over 20 years of experience as a Forester with the Maine Forest Service. Before working with the Maine Forest Service, she worked as a Landowner Assistance Forester for Georgia Pacific Corporation. She also holds a Bachelor of Science in Forest Management from the University of Maine at Orono and has been a strong advocate for forest fire prevention and management, serving on multiple forestry committees, including the National Fire Committee and the Northeast-Midwest State Foresters Association Fire Committee and the Cooperative Forest Fire Prevention committee.

The NASF is a non-profit organization representing forestry agency directors from all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and eight U.S. territories. The association promotes the sustainable management of state and private forests, which comprise two-thirds of the nation's forested lands. Since its founding in 1920, NASF has worked to conserve and protect forest resources and advocate for sustainable forestry in rural and urban environments.

Cormier's election as President comes at a critical time, as state foresters face growing challenges related to climate change, wildfire management, and the protection of forest resources.

urn:contentItem:6DNH-R2V1-DY7R-R406-00000-00Research on Natural Hazards Research Reported by Researchers at Finnish Meteorological Institute (Statistical calibration of probabilistic medium-range Fire Weather Index forecasts in Europe)2024-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisNATURAL HAZARDS RESEARCHResearch on Natural Hazards Research Reported by Researchers at Finnish Meteorological Institute (Statistical calibration of probabilistic medium-range Fire Weather Index forecasts in Europe)


2024 DEC 16 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in natural hazards research. According to news reporting originating from Helsinki, Finland, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Wildfires are increasing in frequency and severity across Europe, which makes accurate wildfire risk estimation crucial for decision-makers and emergency responders."


Financial supporters for this research include Horizon 2020.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Finnish Meteorological Institute: "Wildfire risk is usually estimated using meteorological-based fire weather indices such as the Canadian Forest Fire Weather Index (FWI). By using weather forecasts, the FWI can be predicted for several days and even weeks ahead. Probabilistic ensemble forecasts require verification and calibration in order to provide reliable and accurate forecasts, which are crucial for informed decision-making and an effective emergency response. In this study, we investigate the potential of non-homogeneous Gaussian regression (NGR) for statistically calibrating ensemble forecasts of the FWI. The FWI is calculated using medium-range ensemble forecasts from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) with lead times up to 15 d over Europe. The method is tested using a 30 d rolling training period and dividing the European region into three training areas (northern, central, and Mediterranean Europe)."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The calibration improves FWI forecast particularly at shorter lead times up to 84 h and in regions with elevated FWI values, i.e. areas with a higher wildfire risk such as central and Mediterranean Europe. The study demonstrates that NGR can be used to improve probabilistic FWI forecasts especially in the time range most critical for firefighting resource management and thereby supporting effective wildfire response strategies."
For more information on this research see: Statistical calibration of probabilistic medium-range Fire Weather Index forecasts in Europe. Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences, 2024,24():4225-4235. (Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences - http://www.nat-hazards-earth-syst-sci.net/volumes_and_issues.html). The publisher for Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences is Copernicus Publications.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.5194/nhess-24-4225-2024.

urn:contentItem:69NF-CH71-JBTP-M1VD-00000-00Forest fire along in I-40 Gorge in Harmon Den continues to grow in size2023-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSForest fire along in I-40 Gorge in Harmon Den continues to grow in sizeAarik LongThe Mountaineer, Waynesville, N.C.

Nov. 16—A forest fire is raging in the Harmon Den area of the Pisgah National Forest in Haywood County after being sparked by a tractor-trailer wreck on I-40 in the remote Pigeon River Gorge.

The wreck occurred three miles from the Tennessee state line Thursday morning, and the resulting forest fire spread quickly through the steep, rugged terrain and continued to grow overnight.

The Black Bear Fire had reached 150 acres by mid-afternoon Thursday and was 0% contained, according to the US Forest Service. At noon, the fire had been just 40 acres, showing how quickly it spread upslope in the current drought conditions.

"Fire activity is very active, moving up a ridge through dry fuels," according to a forest service press release.

As the fire spread up the steep terrain, the safety of hikers along the Appalachian Trail — which passes through the area — became a concern.

Haywood County Emergency Service began working to alert hikers of the fire danger, Haywood County Emergency Services Public Information Officer Allison Richmond said. The Appalachian Trail between I-40 and Max Patch has been closed, and hikers already in the area were instructed to leave immediately.

The N.C. Forest Service and U.S. Forest Service led the assault on the fire Thursday. Personnel and equipment on scene included air attack, air tankers, helicopters, a 20-person hand crew, and dozers. Aircraft dropped water and retardant to slow the fire progression.

Resources from the Southern Area Blue Team — which has been fighting the massive forest fire in Cherokee County — were being mobilized to the Black Bear Fire and would assume command once they arrived.

The accident occurred around 8 a.m., about 3.5 miles from the state line. When the fire first started along the interstate, smoke impacted visibility for motorists, North Carolina State Highway Patrol First Sgt. Brent Hipp said. Motorists are cautioned about smoke still lingering in the area.

State troopers have closed Cold Springs Creek Road and Brown Mountain Road near I-40 exit 7 to keep people away from the fire.

urn:contentItem:695F-0051-JBSP-13N1-00000-00Lancaster University Reports Findings in Anxiety Disorders (Developing and Validating a Scale for Anxiety Over Land and Forest Fire)2023-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisMENTAL HEALTH DISEASES AND CONDITIONS - ANXIETY DISORDERSLancaster University Reports Findings in Anxiety Disorders (Developing and Validating a Scale for Anxiety Over Land and Forest Fire)


2023 SEP 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Health & Medicine Daily -- Data detailed on Mental Health Diseases and Conditions - Anxiety Disorders have been presented. According to news reporting out of Lancaster, United Kingdom, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Anxiety related to disasters is a topic of emergent research significance. Literature has shown that the potential occurrence of disasters can trigger feelings of anxiety for individuals."


Financial support for this research came from Ministry of Research and Technology of the Republic of Indonesia (RISTEK).
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Lancaster University, "While a scale for measuring general anxiety and anxiety symptoms exists, a scale that measures worried thoughts related to land and forest fire is not yet available in the disaster and land and forest fire literature. The aim of this research was to measure and develop a valid scale for worried thoughts related to land and forest fire. We mapped worried thoughts related to land and forest fire onto anxiety over land and forest fire. We used focus groups to generate items for anxiety over land and forest fire and validated the scale for anxiety over land and forest fire. We used an online sur-vey to collect the data in Indonesia and we targeted residents who live near the fire prone areas in Kalimantan and Sumatra islands of Indonesia as participants. Through a systematic scale devel-opment procedure: Exploratory Factor Analysis (n=430), Confirmatory Factor Analysis (n=252), Confirmatory Factor Analysis for external validity (n=254), we developed a three -dimension scale for anxiety over land and forest fire i.e., habitat loss-related anxiety, economic and financial-related anxiety, and health-related anxiety. A further nomological network (n=370) established the validity and reliability of the scale."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Our newly developed scale is found to be psychometrically sound as a valid instrument for the purpose of measuring anxiety over land and forest fire."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Developing and Validating a Scale for Anxiety Over Land and Forest Fire. International Journal of Disaster Risk Reduction, 2023;95. urn:contentItem:6F3F-5GC3-RTVK-53RG-00000-00Musician Nikhil Dasgupta returns to music after fluke injury and chronic illness2025-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisMusician Nikhil Dasgupta returns to music after fluke injury and chronic illnessBy Aimsel Ponti Portland Press Herald

Singer-songwriter Nikhil Dasgupta, a 2016 Bowdoin College graduate, released the song "Heaven Knows" on Feb. 6.

The song is gorgeous, delicate and sprinkled with Dasgupta's piano and guitar and swirls of synth sounds created by his longtime friend Sam Kyzivat. Dasgupta's voice is tender yet sturdy. Emotions are running high as he sings about the heartache of a failed relationship.

I won't spend another year in denial, and you won't change your mind
Still I can't help but love you like a forest fire, heaven knows I've tried

Dasgupta lives just outside of Boston in Allston, Massachusetts. How he came to live there is a story that was born of trauma, but one that has led him to a happier  existence.

In April 2019, Dasgupta was closing a vertical window in his Portland apartment when it fell out of its frame, hitting him in the head.

The moment changed his life forever when the injury shifted from a simple concussion into a full-blown health crisis.

Nearly six years later, Dasgupta, now 30, shared during a Zoom interview that despite everything he's been through, he's more at peace than ever before.

I first became aware of Dasgupta when his band SnugHouse (named for the pub he lived above) released its debut, self-titled EP in 2017.

It was love at first listen when I heard the harmony-rich "I Couldn't Be." The song still knocks me sideways.

The "Like Water" EP followed in 2018 with the track "Firefly" followed by the bright and breezy single "Irie."

That same year, SnugHouse played at the Old Port Festival and that fall played to a pretty packed house at One Longfellow Square. In 2019, SnugHouse performed as part of Coffee By Design's 25th anniversary celebration.

Sometime around then, Dasgupta and I met for coffee so he could ask for advice on promoting the band. I remember thinking that he seemed extremely focused and eager to bring more attention to SnugHouse.

But then the shows abruptly stopped, as did any new music from SnugHouse. I remember hearing that Dasgupta had been either injured or was ill.

Two weeks ago, Dasgputa reached out with the news about "Heaven Knows."

He shared that initially when the window fell on him, he experienced classic symptoms of concussion that he assumed would clear up within a few weeks. But when they didn't, Dasgupta retreated to his parents' house in Massachusetts to recover, while the rest of SnugHouse tried to salvage its first tour. "I think it kind of triggered some sort of kind of systemic thing, and I think it turned into a kind of PTSD with a lot of neurological problems," said Dasgupta.

He developed an acute sensitivity to screens and sounds, along with severe dizziness, rendering Dasgupta unable to play or even listen to music. For a year, Dasgupta even had to shower with earplugs because he couldn't tolerate the sound of water.

His doctors believed he was suffering from chronic Lyme disease, but tests were inconclusive. "My takeaway from this is that it's a gray area of medicine. Long Covid is very similar, where people just have all the symptoms and no one really understands," he said.

These days, Dasgupta doesn't focus on a diagnosis. "The conventional medical system doesn't seem to have answers for me right now and I know what I have to do. I have to try and find meaning and happiness in each day."

To that end, Dasgupta pays close attention to what he eats and how much sleep and exercise he gets. He also gave up consuming alcohol permanently.

"I'm not gonna obsess over what went wrong, and in the end I think that the almost spiritual separation from looking for answers is what kind of helped to get me to where I am now, where I'm more at peace then I've ever been. "

However, Dasgupta also had to reckon with the idea that he may never be able to play music, a huge part of his identity.

But during a particularly dark period in 2020 grappling with both health issues and heartache, the concept for "Heaven Knows" came to him. "Simply put, it was about a relationship. Those are very poignant emotions for all of us as humans and it was about kind of surrendering to helplessness," said Dasgupta.

Last year, Dasgupta submitted an early version of the song to Boston public radio station WBUR as part of its Tiny Desk Concert contest. Although he didn't win, the panel at the station loved the song and it was a top five contender.

Dasgupta recorded a more formal version of "Heaven Knows" in his home studio and it can be streamed everywhere.

Dasgupta no longer has dreams of touring the country and releasing a steady flow of music, but he also knows that music is in his core. He has a goal of playing one headlining show in 2025. "I am embarking on a journey to figure out what it looks like."

To keep up with his music and any future live appearance, follow Dasgupta on Instagram (@nyquildasgupta) and sign-up for his mailing list at nikhildasgupta.com.

urn:contentItem:6DVY-V6M3-RSXB-P2FB-00000-00Post wrongly links directed energy weapons to Los Angeles wildfires | Fact check2025-01-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisPost wrongly links directed energy weapons to Los Angeles wildfires | Fact checkThe claim: Image shows directed energy weapons caused 2025 wildfires in Los Angeles

A Jan. 8 Facebook post (direct link, archive link) shows a fast-food restaurant that burned down in a wooded area.

"This is a McDonalds (sic) in California that was just destroyed by a forest fire," the post reads. "You can see the forest said to be responsible in the background. Just dew it."

The acronym DEW is an apparent reference to directed energy weapons.

The post also includes an image of the fictional Dr. Evil character from the "Austin Powers" film series gesturing air quotes with text in the image that reads, "'Forest fires.'"

It was shared more than 100 times in two days.

More from the Fact-Check Team:How we pick and research claims | Email newsletter | Facebook page

Our rating: False

The causes of the Los Angeles fires had not been announced as of Jan. 10. There is no credible evidence that the fires were caused by directed energy weapons, which have repeatedly – and falsely – been linked to high-profile wildfires for years.

No evidence directed energy weapons caused California wildfires

The claim was made as multiple deadly fires burned across the Los Angeles area, leaving more than 10,000 structures damaged or destroyed and at least 10 people dead as of Jan. 10.

But the post is wrong in its claim that the image shows a McDonald's restaurant that was "just destroyed" in a California fire. The restaurant in the image was burned in the 2018 Camp Fire in the Northern California town of Paradise. The news outlet WHYY included the image, taken by an Associated Press photographer, in a 2018 report about the blaze.

There is also no evidence directed energy weapons caused the 2025 fires in Southern California. There have been no credible government or news reports about such a determination. The causes of the fires (Palisades, Eaton, Hurst, Lidia, Sunset, Kenneth and Archer) remain under investigation as of Jan. 10, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, the state's firefighting agency.

Fact check: Was Hollywood Sign surrounded by fire? No, this image is fabricated

Directed energy weapons use concentrated electromagnetic energy to damage or destroy enemy targets, according to the U.S. Government Accountability Office. Social media users have repeatedly – and falsely – linked these weapons to high-profile fires over the years. USA TODAY debunked similar claims about wildfires in Hawaii and Texas.

A broken electrical transmission line caused the 2018 fire that devastated Paradise. That fire destroyed more than 18,000 structures and killed 85 people.

USA TODAY reached out to the Facebook user who shared the post for comment but did not immediately receive a response.

urn:contentItem:6DF4-W561-DY83-T190-00000-00California officials removing 'squaw' from state names by Jan. 12024-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisCalifornia officials removing 'squaw' from state names by Jan. 1MIKE HEUERNov. 16

More than 30 geographic formations and locales in California no longer will include the word "squaw" due to its offensive nature.

State lawmakers in 2022 approved and Governor Gavin Newsom signed into law Assembly Bill 2022, which requires the state to identify and remove the word "squaw" from streets, public buildings, bridges, cemeteries and forest fire fuel breaks.

The California Advisory Committee on Geographic Names in February provided state lawmakers with a list of named places and features throughout the state that included "squaw" in their names.

"The term 'squaw' has been used historically as an offensive ethnic, racial and sexist slur, specifically towards indigenous women," the California Natural Resources Agency said in a news release on Feb. 7.

California's advisory committee sifted through state maps to identify any uses of the word and compile a list of needed name changes.

The list uses the term "sq__" in place of the word "squaw," and the agency does not use the full word in its communications.

The California Advisory Committee on Geographic Names is working to complete the name changes by the end of the year.

New names will go in place of the ones deemed offensive with the help of aboriginal tribes located within California.

An example of acceptable name changes is the recent re-naming of two streets in West Sacramento to include the aboriginal word "tebti," which refers to two streams that flow together and traditionally is used as a blessing.

Members of the Yocha Dehe Wintun Nation helped local officials determine suitable new names for the two streets and suggested using "tebti."

The Squaw Valley Alphine Meadows resort, site of 1960 Olympic Games' events and the village, changed its name to Palisades Tahoe in 2021. The region Squaw Valley was renamed Olympic Valley in 2022.

The U.S. Department of Interior similarly ordered the removal of offensive names from national landmarks and other locations located on federal lands.

urn:contentItem:6G2W-G203-RRTB-C29P-00000-00Tree methane exchange in a changing world2025-11-15T08:20:12Z2025-11-15T08:20:12ZLexisNexisPg. 471-483Tree methane exchange in a changing world

Publisher’s note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

Tree surfaces facilitate methane (CH4) exchange between terrestrial systems and the atmosphere. In this Perspective, I consider methane emission and uptake in trees, the underlying mechanisms and their response to environmental changes. Methane emitted from trees predominantly originates in soils, being transferred through the stem. The highest tree methane emissions occur in waterlogged soil conditions. As such, trees in wetland and riparian forests are a net source of methane, with topical wetland trees emitting up to ~44 Tg CH4 yr−1. By comparison, trees on free-draining upland soils are a net sink of methane on the order of 50 Tg CH4 yr−1, with microbially mediated methanotrophy along the soil–tree continuum dominating the vertical attenuation of soil-derived methane fluxes.

Latitude (temperature) and nutrient status also influence net methane exchange. For example, tree methane emissions in the more nutrient-replete Amazon floodplain are up to 1,000-fold higher than those in ombrotrophic peat swamps of Panama and Borneo. Elevated atmospheric CO2 concentrations are predicted to enhance wetland tree methane emissions and reduce upland tree net methane uptake, with the latter effect probably being strongest. Evidence from ice core records suggests that notable changes in global forest cover in the Americas in the 1500s following European first contact might have reduced global atmospheric methane concentrations by up to 50 ppb, indicating that forest area influence over the global methane budget is potentially substantial. Future research should better quantify tree methane exchange responses to environmental changes and reduce uncertainty in the global methane budgets.

Tree methane exchange is an important component of the terrestrial and global methane budget. This Perspective explores the mechanisms underlying why wetland trees are a net source of methane to the atmosphere and upland trees are a net sink, and the effect environmental changes will have on these processes.

IntroductionMethane (CH4) is the second most important anthropogenically enhanced greenhouse gas1. Atmospheric concentrations of methane have dramatically increased from a pre-industrial baseline of ~700 ppb (ref. 2) to modern levels in excess of 1,900 ppb (ref. 3), with the rate of increase reaching 12.7 ppb yr−1 between 2014 and 2017 (ref. 4). Atmospheric sinks (hydroxyl (OH)-radicals) dominate methane losses at the global scale5. As a result, the atmospheric lifetime of methane is only about a decade, meaning that atmospheric levels can reflect short-term variations in components of the methane budget6. However, there is uncertainty over the size of the atmospheric sink7 and the global methane budget cannot be closed, partly owing to bottom-up emissions estimates exceeding those of top-down estimates by ~94 Tg yr−1 (ref. 5). As the terrestrial methane sink is thought to solely comprise the relatively small soil sink5, it is possible that the observed disparities between estimates results from a substantial terrestrial sink either being omitted or poorly represented in global methane budget estimates.

Trees, their bark and foliage facilitate the exchange of methane between the land surface and the atmosphere8, 9–10. For example, half of all methane emissions from the Amazon are emitted from floodplain trees11. Indeed, flooded or high water table trees mediate up to half (~44 Tg yr−1) of all tropical forested wetland methane emissions12. In wetlands with hypoxic and anoxic soils, tree morphological adaptations — such as the development of hollow aerenchyma tissue — facilitate air ingress into the rhizosphere13 and further permit soil-produced methane to exit via the same pathway14. Conversely, upland trees on free-draining, non-flooded soils, are net methane sinks15 on the order of 25–50 Tg yr−1 (ref. 15), potentially matching or exceeding the size of the terrestrial soil methane sink5,15. Consumption of methane by methanotrophic bacteria living in and on tree stems probably dominates tree uptake of atmospheric methane15.

Globally, there are an estimated 3 trillion trees16 in forests spanning ~4,000 Mha across lowland tropical to arctic and alpine environments17. Woody surfaces alone can provide a surface area of biosphere–atmosphere contact that is equal to that of the global land surface15. Thus, given the need to understand how all components of the methane cycle contribute to the atmospheric burden, constraining how different agents of global change influence trees and forests will help the accurate quantification and prediction of responses in the global methane cycle and budget. Such insights will help reduce uncertainties in the global methane budget and support efforts towards meeting Paris Agreement targets for climate change18.

In this Perspective, I summarize the processes and mechanisms driving methane emission and uptake by trees. Then I discuss the response of tree methane exchange to global changes, including land use, warming, precipitation changes and elevated atmospheric CO2 concentrations. Next, I consider the role of trees in the past and future methane cycle. Finally, I highlight priorities for future research, including extending observations networks, interrogating past atmospheric methane fluctuations preserved in ice core records and leveraging forest ecosystem experiments to understand forest methane exchange sensitivity to environmental change.

Tree methane exchange with the atmosphere

Trees, their bark and foliage, provide an additional surface for methane exchange between the land surface and the atmosphere, with woody surfaces alone providing an area of biosphere–atmosphere contact that is as vast as that of the global land surface15. The mechanisms of methane emissions and uptake by trees are now discussed.

Methane emissions from trees

Observations of tree methane fluxes are biased towards tropical wetlands and forests (Fig. 1). Available evidence suggests that wetland trees dominate methane emissions, although smaller emissions fluxes are also observed in upland trees on portions of the trunk near the forest floor15,19.

Net methane emission from trees is the product of the competing processes of anaerobic methane production and aerobic methane oxidation in wetland soils20. It occurs by methanogenesis under anaerobic conditions in wetland soils14 and, to a much lesser and highly uncertain extent, within trees themselves. Conversely, methane oxidation (methanotrophy) is facilitated by microbes along the soil–tree continuum and within the tree bark, which attenuates methane emissions from the tree stem to the atmosphere21,22 (Fig. 2a).Fig. 1

Global distribution of wetland tree methane (CH4) exchange observations.

a, The global distribution of wetland tree stem methane emission observations. Data from ref. 25. b, Methane tree emissions for selected tropical forest wetland biomes of varied nutrient status. Amazon floodplains include the Tapajos River floodplain (mineral-rich, clear water) and Negro River (acidic and humic). Ombrotrophic peat swamps are presented for Panama (San San Pond Sak wetland) and Borneo (Sebangau National Park, Central Kalimantan, Indonesia). The Amazon floodplain and global average emissions are displayed on the left y axis and the ombrotrophic peat swap emissions are displayed on the right y axis. Global wetland tree emission investigations span a range of wetland ecosystem types of varying nutrient status and methane productivity, with African wetland trees being severely under-represented.

Fig. 2

Methane (CH4) cycling and transfer within trees and their surroundings.

a, Methane production, cycling and emission from wetland-adapted trees experiencing inundation and a high water table. b, Methane cycling in wetland-adapted trees experiencing seasonal or exceptional drought (where transport of atmospheric methane is hypothesized to also reach the rhizosphere through wetland-adapted aerenchyma). The bold black arrows represent internal tree microbial methane production and oxidation (cycling), the solid arrows represent the net direction of methane flow, dashed arrows represent microbial oxidation and attenuation of emissions, blue circles represent methane consumption and red circles represent methane production. The question marks in a and b denote high uncertainty in methane exchange. c, Hypothetical forest methane production and stem flux responses to variable soil moisture availability. The left on the x axis represents progressively arid environments and the right on the x axis represents progressively humid and waterlogged environments. The dashed vertical line represents the transition to saturated soil conditions and yellow shaded area represents net soil methane production. Adapted with permission from ref. 18. Methane production and emission or uptake via tree stems is governed, principally, by soil hydrology.

Soil-produced methane is the dominant source of tree-emitted methane. Although bark-transmitted emissions can occur independently of transpiration22, tree methane emissions are generally controlled by hydrology via diffusion or transpiration14. Net primary production also governs methane production23. Methane production has a tight dependence on net primary productivity through its influence on available substrates via root exudates24, fine root and leaf litter. Both carbon production and carbon allocation within trees and to forest soils can determine net fluxes.

Methane emissions from tree stems vary with environmental conditions. Tree stem emissions can range by several orders of magnitude depending on latitude (which is closely related to mean annual temperature)25, hydrological12 (for example, floodplain11,12 versus peatland20,26, 27–28) and nutrient status (such as mineral-rich Amazonian floodplain versus ombrotrophic peatland). Observed emission rates range from 10s of µg m−2 h−1 in ombrotrophic peat swamps20,27 to ~140 mg m−2 h−1 in floodplains of mineral-rich clear water rivers of the Amazon11 (Fig. 1).

Tree traits9 and proximity to the coast also influence emissions. Stem lenticel density29 and wood density27 are important regulators of wetland tree methane emissions25. Inland wetland trees exhibit relatively high emissions compared with coastal mangrove trees (with notable exceptions30)25,31. This contrast is in part attributed to sulfate inhibition of coastal mangrove tree emissions, whereby sulfate-reducing bacteria competitively exclude methanogenesis when substrates are limiting32, 33–34. Whether wetland tree species are angiosperms (high emissions) or gymnosperms (very low emissions by comparison)25 also influence emissions. Though small, emissions measured in gymnosperm needle leaves and shoots35 are thought to reflect a highly uncertain aerobic foliar methane source36,37. In addition, tree traits related to transport and diffusion (such as rooting depth) or microbial mechanisms can influence exchange9. However, the effects of nutrient status have not yet been considered, despite probably having a strong influence on emission flux rates (Fig. 1).

Although methanogenesis is associated with waterlogged anaerobic soil conditions, trees in upland free-draining soils can also emit methane. Evidence comes from observations of the accessible lower tree stem portions of upland trees19,38, 39, 40–41 and in wetland-adapted tropical floodplain trees under temporarily low water table conditions that can be considered functionally upland12,15. Given the low water table, these emissions most probably derive from anaerobic microsites within free-draining soils42,43. These upland tree emissions are typically orders of magnitude smaller than those of wetland trees and decline with height above the forest floor until 1.5 m when average fluxes become negative and the tree stem above that height acts as a methane sink15.

Observations are biased towards sampling lower stem sections, potentially misrepresenting whole-tree methane fluxes. Typically, fluxes are reported at 1.3 m (breast height) above the forest floor25. Thus, sampling probably captures methane emissions and omits uptake, which is more prevalent higher up in the tree (as confirmed by measurements on stems and branches at 2, 5 and 11 m above the forest floor)15. However, available evidence suggests that methane is also emitted by leaves in some trees. For example, immature Amazon floodplain tree leaves11 and pioneer tree species sampled at around 1.2 m above the forest floor in Bangladesh10 exhibit small foliar emissions. These emissions are attributed to the entrainment of soil-produced methane by this successional class of trees having higher xylem flow rates that promote foliar methane emissions, which is not the case for later stage successional classes10.

Methane uptake by trees

Microbial methanotrophy governs methane consumption (oxidation) and potential net uptake in trees. Methane oxidation in free-draining upland soils is thought to account for ~30 Tg of methane removal from the atmosphere each year44. Although generally occurring in the rhizosphere of herbaceous wetland plants45, 46–47, methanotrophy has also been observed in Australian wetland Melaleuca trees where as much as 33% of emissions were mitigated by methanotrophy between lower and upper tree stem portions21. There is an increasing body of evidence to suggest that methane consumption and uptake can occur within48 and on the surfaces of trees. When upscaled, methane uptake by trees globally could account for 25–50 Tg of atmospheric methane removal15.

Tree stems uptake of methane from the atmosphere has been observed across a range of forest types and locations. There is evidence of tree methane uptake in boreal forests of Scandinavia49,50, temperate forests51 and tropical forests, including those of La Reunion in the Indian Ocean52 and the Amazon floodplain during low water dry seasons12, and spanning a transect of a boreal to tropical climate gradient15 (including Sweden, the UK, Panama and the Amazon forest15). However, despite the region’s importance, few data exist for Africa53.

As with wetland tree methane emissions, there is a distinct vertical variation in methane uptake along the tree stem. After emissions diminish near the tree base, atmospheric methane uptake then increases with distance from the forest floor15. The change in flux direction and magnitude, together with likely changes in bark methanotroph methane affinity with increasing height above the forest floor15, suggests a response in net methane exchange attributed to competing processes varying in the vertical plane (Fig. 3). The relative importance of each process is governed by the hydrological status of the soil and other variables, such as the presence or absence of tree morphological adaptations to periods of inundation13 (as is the case in the Amazon floodplains). In this example, tree root aeration apparatus might further permit mass flow of methane to the rhizosphere where it can be consumed by soil methanotrophs (Fig. 2b).Fig. 3

Idealized variability in methane processes with height above ground.

Competing methane (CH4) processes in trees growing in wetland soils (solid line) and upland soils (dashed line) are shown on the left. The combined net influence of these competing processes is shown on the far right. Note the exaggerated representation of transiting soil methane for upland soils. Methane-relevant processes operating across the soil–tree–atmosphere continuum are spatially disaggregated in the vertical plane.

There is a clear need to better characterize methane exchange across woody surfaces. Given the spatial disaggregation of processes and evidence of increasing uptake with distance from the forest floor, it can be anticipated that uptake fluxes exceed those used in global scaling, potentially leading to the global tree methane sink being underestimated.

Given the range of factors involved in determining both tree methane emission and uptake, there is potential for each of these to respond differently to agents of global change with a net global forest methane exchange outcome that can be either more methanogenic or more methanotrophic.

Response of tree methane to global change

The net response of methane production and oxidation in soils and tree stems to environmental changes is uncertain; however, inferences can be made based on analogous systems. The influence of changes in forest extent, temperature and precipitation, and elevated atmospheric CO2 on net tree methane exchange are now discussed.

Land-use change

Forest extent is a primary control on global scale tree methane fluxes. In 2015, the global forest area was ~4,000 Mha (ref. 17) — equivalent to ~30% of the Earth’s land surface — with 52% in tropical and subtropical zones, and 26% and 22% in temperate and boreal zones, respectively17. Other wooded lands (land with trees but not categorized as forest) cover ~1,200 Mha (ref. 17). Forest area is highly variable over time owing to climate change, deforestation and afforestation, wildfire (an additional source of methane54), and climate-induced mass forest die back55,56. In 2024, global woody plant surface area was estimated at 146 million km2 (ref. 15), an area equivalent to the global land surface area. Thus, any change in forest area, composition or function presents a clear mechanism to alter biosphere–atmosphere exchange of methane in globally important quantities.

The type of forest subject to land-use change will also impact the magnitude of the impact on tree methane fluxes. This biome-specific shift in forest area is crucial to quantify is crucial as changes in forest area in wetland or upland environments will have different net effects on tree methane sources12 and sinks15. For example, there has been widespread deforestation and drainage in Southeast Asian peat swamp forests since the mid-1800s (ref. 57). Between 1990 and 2015, 71% of wetlands were converted (mostly to palm oil plantations), with peat swamp forest cover only remaining on 4.6 Mha of peatlands in the region, which spans Indonesia and Malaysia57. However, Southeast Asian peat swamp forests have low nutrient ombrotophic status27,58 and, as such, are a relatively small source of methane when compared with tree emissions from nutrient-replete tropical seasonal floodplain forests11,12 (Fig. 1). However, assessing tree methane impacts in such regions is challenging as drainage waters from deforested areas of Southeast Asian peat swamps are substantial methane emission sources59 and emissions from replacement agroecosystems, such as Acacia sp. plantations, are up to 50% of those of intact peat swamp forest ecosystems60.

Trees within the pulsing freshwater system of the Amazon floodplain emit up to 21 Tg yr−1 methane12 and are subject to a range of environmental pressures61,62. Changes in floodplain and forest extent, and alterations to the flood pulse through construction of upstream dams62, all have the potential to influence methane emissions from floodplain trees. For example, since 1980, climate change has increased the maximum flood extent in the Amazon by 26% (ref. 63). Assuming inundation adaptation among newly inundated trees or broader ecosystem adaptation, these changes could have resulted in tree methane emissions being elevated to globally important levels. However, portions of the lower Amazon are experiencing ~50% floodplain deforestation64, affecting many riparian areas, which are sources of tree methane emissions12. Collectively, mining, dam building, deforestation and climate change all affect the hydrological and biogeochemical functioning of floodplain forests, with uncertain consequences for biome-wide wetland tree methane emissions.

Upland forests have experienced extensive deforestation, globally losing 3% of forest area between 1990 and 2015 (ref. 17). Since 2001, upland forest loss resulted from a combination of permanent land-use change for commodity production, forestry, shifting agriculture and wildfire in similar proportions65. In total, global forest cover has diminished from 6 billion ha at the start of the Holocene 10,000 years ago to 4 billion ha in the first quarter of the twenty-first century, representing a decline from 57% to 38% of total land cover66. These changes will have reduced the tree surface sink term and will have shifted vegetated land surfaces towards a methanogenic state, through the hydrological effects of reduced evapotranspiration and increased run off increasing wetland area67. By contrast, although standing dead trees and decaying coarse woody debris can be a methane source68,69, coarse woody debris at the forest floor resulting from deforestation and other activities would tend to act as a methane sink70. Accounting for global shifts in forest demography and mortality71, this link with forest methane exchange requires further examination.

In addition, as with soil uptake, tree methane uptake is probably also controlled by atmospheric concentrations72, which were relatively small during the pre-industrial Holocene73 and so reducing uptake rates, which vary with atmospheric methane concentrations (smaller atmospheric concentrations lead to smaller fluxes). Conversely, uptake rates will probably be larger in the future when atmospheric methane concentrations are projected to be higher.

Changes in temperature and precipitation

Methanotrophy in soils is a potential analogue for the behaviour of woody surface methanotrophy. In soils, methanotrophy is limited by moisture availability, temperature and diffusive transport of methane to the uptake site72. Within a given climatic zone, hydrology is a primary control on methanotrophy as water availability probably governs soil and tree methane production and oxidation. Responses in microbial community composition, tree taxonomy and their associated methane-relevant traits to soil hydrology probably further affect net methane exchange8,40,74,75 (Fig. 2c).

Forests have the capacity to modify multiple processes that are relevant to the cycling of methane in response to climate change and its drivers, directly and indirectly. Direct effects of climate change include the net outcome of different temperature responses between the competing processes of methanogenesis and methanotrophy, and the influence of moisture availability on these processes. Indirect effects include the cascading effects of how productivity within forests responds to climate. For instance, warming might increase productivity and labile substrate allocation to soils76 that, if wet, could boost methane production and reduce the uptake of atmospheric methane.

Q10 temperature coefficients reflect how much the rate of a biological process changes for every 10 °C increase in temperature. Q10 values have not been quantified for methanogenesis or methanotrophy within or on tree surfaces and so inferences must be made based on observations of soil systems and other vegetated surfaces. The Q10 values for wetland methane emissions vary between 1.7 and 16 (ref. 77) and vary in rice paddies between 1.5 and 3 (ref. 78). The latter probably being closer to Q10 values in high pH tropical forested wetlands that are most likely to follow a similar proportion of acetate metabolism (up to 80%) as the methane precursor to rice paddy methane production79. In contrast, soil methanotrophy does not respond as strongly to temperature, with Q10 values ranging from 1 to 2 (refs. 80, 81–82). In forest soils, warming inconsistently affects uptake of atmospheric methane83, suggesting that other factors, such as diffusion rates, limit activity81. Overall, the responses of trees to direct climate change are highly uncertain, although Q10 values for methanogenesis exceed those of methanotrophy, suggesting that warming favours methane production over consumption in trees.

Methanogenesis and methanotrophy are both highly dependent on moisture availability. Saturated water conditions promote methane production and emission from wetland trees26 and, less frequently, upland tree bases19, provided there is a transport mechanism for methane egress as gas transfer is typically impeded in saturated soils81. Conversely, aridity impedes both methanogenesis and methane uptake81,83. However, drought of unspecified severity enhanced soil methane uptake in 11 forest experiments spanning a range of bioclimatic zones83, probably owing to reduced methanogenesis at anaerobic microsites in otherwise free-draining upland soils but without insufficient aridity to limit methanotrophy83. Depending on tree water demands, this limitation of anaerobic methanogenic microsites would shift the total tree exchange balance in favour of methane uptake.

Other factors that shift tree methane exchange in favour of methane oxidation can also respond to global change. Sulfate is an alternate electron acceptor supplied globally in fossil fuel-derived pollution. Sulfate-reducing bacteria outcompete methanogens for substrates33,84, resulting in decreased methane production in soils. Therefore, air pollution legislation to reduce this sulfate source could result in greater methanogenesis in wetland soils and, conceivably, upland soils, potentially decreasing net tree methane uptake in the future85.

Tree bark is also susceptible to local environmental change. Although direct evidence is lacking, it is likely that high vapour pressure deficits will affect tree bark methane exchange. More specifically, bark interception of methane (either uptake or emission) will decrease under sufficiently low moisture availability to impair endophytic methanotrophy83. Despite these uncertainties, there have been attempts to represent tree methane emissions in estimates of future ecosystem responses to climate change. For example, representation of methane emissions from tropical wetland trees in wetland responses to different climate scenarios where trees are assumed to emit half of all tropical wetland emissions23. Such findings are in agreement with budgets where inclusion of tree emissions reconciled top-down and bottom-up methane emission estimates in the Amazon11. As climate-induced changes in wetland emissions are estimated to range from an additional 0.6 to 5.5% over the 21st century, there is a clear need to refine tree representation in global climate models so that all processes related to methanogenesis, transport and uptake are fully represented.

Influence of increasing atmospheric CO2

Atmospheric CO2 continues to increase. Depending on the scenario considered, concentrations could reach around 506 ppm by 2050 and 602 ppm by 2100 under a moderate Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP2-4.5)86. Broad physiological responses of growing plantation and mature trees to elevated CO2 (eCO2) have been examined in the temperate northern hemisphere (Duke FACE87, BIFoR FACE88,89, SPRUCE90 and in Switzerland91,92) and subtropical Australia (EucFACE)93,94, with upcoming free-air CO2 enrichment (FACE) experiments planned for the Amazon forest near Manaus in Brazil (AmazonFACE95). However, measurements of within or subcanopy methane exchange in these large-scale experiments are incredibly scarce. Tree transpiration partially controls the amount of water stored in soils that, in turn, controls the capacity of soils to produce or consume methane. Increases in atmospheric CO2 concentrations (eCO2) are modifying plant water-use efficiency through modified stomatal control96. At the leaf level, these modifications reduce the amount of water plants transpire97. Plant stomata respond to elevated atmospheric CO2 concentrations by narrowing their opening to conserve moisture (with sufficient CO2 for photosynthesis maintained in a CO2-enriched atmosphere), ultimately increasing soil moisture83.

However, the mechanism of reduced evapotranspiration at the leaf level from eCO2 could be nullified by a corresponding increase in leaf area98,99, with more leaves compensating for eCO2-reduced stomatal conductance. Synthesized evidence of soil methane exchange in seven elevated CO2 experiments indicates a 33% decrease in methane uptake under eCO2 exposure relative to controls. This decrease in methane uptake is associated with increases in soil moisture83, supporting the hypothesis that eCO2 increases water use efficiency and favours net methanogenesis over methanotrophy.

Canopy leaf methane exchange in trees is poorly constrained owing to the scarcity of observations and contradictory nature of existing data10,11,51,100. For example, notable methane uptake has been observed in canopy leaves of Canadian temperate upland trees51, whereas small emissions were recorded in young subcanopy Amazon floodplain tree leaves11 and in near-forest-floor pioneer tree species in Bangladesh10. The possibility remains that methane-utilizing bacteria on leaf surfaces facilitate the apparent leaf uptake of methane and so would not be controlled by stomatal conductance. However, if stomatal exchange is involved in either form of net methane exchange, then stomatal narrowing in response to eCO2 will exert some control over methane fluxes, particularly if soil hydrology is affected, as would be the case in upland trees (Fig. 5).

Finally, an increase in net primary production might result in increased biomass in various structural components of the trees89. Carbohydrate allocation to the soil rhizosphere could also be boosted24,89,101. Together, these effects could impact methanogenic and methanotrophic soil microbial communities and potentially enhance the entrainment, transport and egress of soil methane via roots and stems, resulting in a more methanogenic, or less methanotrophic, forest.

With atmospheric CO2 concentrations continuing to increase, there is a range of sometimes conflicting processes whose outcome might further influence climate via altering tree and forest methane exchange. These include leaf level transpiration responses to eCO2, compensatory ecosystem level responses through enhanced productivity and rhizospheric responses to enhanced carbon allocation, which could determine the methanogenic or methanotrophic status of a forest.

Role in the past and future methane cycle

Forests have experienced change throughout history, from the Pleistocene expansion and contraction across glacial minima and maxima102, to the excesses of twentieth and twenty-first century deforestation66. The emerging understanding of the role of trees in the methane cycle warrants further exploration of past and future global atmospheric change. Ice core records and modern global monitoring networks show striking variations in atmospheric concentrations of methane over millennia and centuries73,103, as well as decades104. Understanding of tree–atmosphere methane exchange presents opportunities to examine how long-term forest changes influenced past atmospheric composition. In addition, individual known past events that impacted forest area over relatively short timescales could be used to constrain the processes in question through analysis of their influence on atmospheric methane as recorded in ice cores105.

Atmospheric methane concentrations rose gradually from ~550 ppb 6,000 years ago106 to 700 pbb at the onset of industrialization73. The cause of this rise is still debated. The impact of human agricultural practices on the Earth system107 and natural responses to changes in orbital configuration108 are two proposed explanations. The so-called Early Anthropogenic (or Anthropocene) Hypothesis109 posits that the altered trajectory of atmospheric methane concentration change 5,000 years ago, as recorded in ice cores, could be attributed to the inception of rice agriculture around that time. Replacement of wetland-adapted and methane-emitting weeds with early planted rice plants, which also emit methane110, means that total wetland area, and so methane source, might not have changed appreciably despite some small-scale irrigation111. However, the impact of associated deforestation on the upland tree methane sink is omitted from this hypothesis. Deforestation would have reduced the tree methane sink in addition to probably increasing wetland area through reduced evapotranspiration67. It is likely that early forest clearance was confined to upland forests, rather than wetland swamps or floodplains, but the potential for global methane impact remains.

Natural forest regeneration on abandoned farmland in the Americas following the arrival of Europeans in the late fifteenth century and the introduction of disease is another period worthy of consideration. The resultant large-scale depopulation of the Americas from ~61 million people in 1492112 to ~6 million people by 1650 coincides with the CO2 minimum, or Orbis Spike, in the Law Dome ice core record dated ~1610112. As a response to the atmospheric drawdown of CO2 in regrowing forests, this CO2 minimum was argued to be a marker for the start of the Anthropocene112, although the cause is still debated113, 114–115.

Ice core records from the Antarctic Law Dome show a methane minimum of 672 ppb preceding the 1610 Orbis Spike by 18 years (in 1592)116. This minimum is preceded by a rapid decline of 50 ppb in atmospheric methane after a peak of 722 ppb in 1561. This decline, which coincides with widespread forest regrowth in the Americas, exceeds other decreases observed in the previous 1,600 years. Owing to its relatively short lifetime, atmospheric methane responds rapidly to any change in sources or sinks. Forest regrowth following depopulation and farmland abandonment was on the order of 250 million ha of forest115,117, savannah and grassland. Increased tree stem surface area would have led to growth in the upland tree woody surface methane sink, reducing atmospheric methane.
